rev.comment: /* "Goodbye, Farewell and Amen" */ unnecessary fair use; not even mentioned, and is used on the appropriate sub article
rev.diff:
Line 333: Line 333:
=="Goodbye, Farewell and Amen"==
=="Goodbye, Farewell and Amen"==
{{main|Goodbye, Farewell and Amen}}
{{main|Goodbye, Farewell and Amen}}
â
[[Image:MASH Goodbye.jpg|thumb|right|Scenes from the series finale.]]
 
"Goodbye, Farewell and Amen" was the final episode of ''M*A*S*H''. The episode aired on [[February 28]], [[1983]], and was 2Â½ hours long. It was viewed by nearly 106 million Americans (77% of viewership that night), which established it as the [[List of most-watched television episodes|most-watched episode]] in United States television history, a record that still stands. The only record it did not break was the highest percentage of homes with television sets to watch a TV series, which is still held by the August 1967 final episode of ''[[The Fugitive (TV series)|The Fugitive]]'', starring David Janssen as Dr. Richard Kimble, which was watched in 72% of all American homes with television sets.
"Goodbye, Farewell and Amen" was the final episode of ''M*A*S*H''. The episode aired on [[February 28]], [[1983]], and was 2Â½ hours long. It was viewed by nearly 106 million Americans (77% of viewership that night), which established it as the [[List of most-watched television episodes|most-watched episode]] in United States television history, a record that still stands. The only record it did not break was the highest percentage of homes with television sets to watch a TV series, which is still held by the August 1967 final episode of ''[[The Fugitive (TV series)|The Fugitive]]'', starring David Janssen as Dr. Richard Kimble, which was watched in 72% of all American homes with television sets.
